dt: {bc}a large, glossy-black bird ({it}Corvus corax{/it}) that is widely distributed in northern parts of the northern hemisphere but now rare in most areas of the eastern and central U.S. and that differs from the closely related common {d_link|crow|crow:1} chiefly in its larger size and wedge-shaped tail and in having the feathers of the throat narrow and pointed resulting in a shaggy appearance
{bc}any of various usually large and glossy black, {d_link|corvine|corvine} birds

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}hræfn{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}hraban{/it} raven, Latin {it}corvus{/it}, Greek {it}korax{/it}
shortdef: a large, glossy-black bird (Corvus corax) that is widely distributed in northern parts of the northern hemisphere but now rare in most areas of the eastern and central U.S. and that differs from the closely related common crow chiefly in its larger size and wedge-shaped tail and in having the feathers of the throat narrow and pointed resulting in a shaggy appearance; also : any of various usually large and glossy black, corvine birds

dt: {bc}shiny and black like a raven's feathers

shortdef: shiny and black like a raven's feathers

dt.t: men … {wi}raven{/wi} the earth, destroying its resources

et: It is pointed out by the {it}Oxford English Dictionary,{/it} third edition, that given the Middle English attestation of the derivatives {it}ravener{/it} "plunderer, predatory animal" and {it}ravening{/it} "rapacious," this verb may also date to Middle English. Compare Anglo-French {it}raviner{/it} "to steal, take away," apparently attested once.

shortdef: a bird that cries at night

dt: Samuel 1793–1863 American general; president of the Republic of Texas (1836–38; 1841–44)

shortdef: Samuel 1793—1863 American general; president of the Republic of Texas (1836—38; 1841—44)
